Posts.Content: Hi keyfeatures, Sounds about like me with the being sick.....did you try starving beforehand? I decided to eat something before Docetaxol because I had to take steroids, but kept it to a minimum. Was OK afterwards apart from my tongue which was completely white and horrible. Ended up going to hospital and being kept in for 48 hours due to low white blood cell count so risk of infection. Pumped full of antibiotics as a precaution which was really annoying as I didn't have an infection anyway just a risk of one.......next dose on Thursday - will let you know how it goes!!!
Posts.Title: Chemo starting next Tuesday

Posts.Content: Hi Anne, Sorry, I forgot to say that I was always sick after FEC but not for a couple of hours. I was advised not to drive myself to and from the hospital as if I had an accident after chemo the insurance may use it as an excuse not to pay out.......I must admit I was always really tired after chemo anyway.
Posts.Title: Chemo starting next Tuesday

Posts.Content: Sounds like a good party trick!! I have been without hair for several months now and have worn a baseball cap with hair attached most of the time. I decided to wear my wig for a change the other day and bumped into our lady postman who immediately said 'I like your hair'. I don't think anyone ever said that to me about my real hair......bonus!!! XXXX
Posts.Title: How did you react to getting your wigs?

Posts.Content: Sounds like a good party trick!! I have been without hair for several months now and have worn a baseball cap with hair attached most of the time. I decided to wear my wig for a change the other day and bumped into our lady postman who immediately said 'I like your hair'. I don't think anyone ever said that to me about my real hair......bonus!!! XXXX
Posts.Title: How did you react to getting your wigs?

Posts.Content: Hi, I am one of the strange ones who has lost 2 stone since diagnosis last April. I just cut out biscuits, cake, white bread, jam etc. Basically most of the rubbish that I used to eat to keep me going through the day. I still do eat chocolate a bit and have the occasional treat but mostly it's fruit and veg for me. I haven't put any weight back on and I've been on Tamoxifen since the beginning December - having said that, this cold winter weather is making me want to eat all the time!! Cassie xx
Posts.Title: how to lose weight on tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Marvellous!! If it's anything like before he'll wake up and the whole series will be a bad dream - shame it's not the same for us:-( xxxxxxxxx
Posts.Title: TRivial BUT..............

Posts.Content: Hi, I had mastectomy and lymph node clearance together on 30th April. Think there may be more risk of lymphodema and cording once all the nodes have been taken away so it is important to follow the excercises they give you. It took quite a while to get full movement of my shoulder back and I did have some cording but this has now improved. I still have a numb area in my armpit which tingles sometimes like you have been stung by stinging nettles. Sometimes my hand and lower arm swells a bit and I have to massage upwards to move the lymph back up my arm. Wasn't really to painful though and I recovered quickly with no bruising or swelling. Hope all goes well - will be thinking of you. Cassie xxx
Posts.Title: Just had telephone assessment/pre op check this morning

Posts.Content: Hi Sascha, Sorry it didn't go as planned - that sounds like a horrible experience and it's a pain that you've got to go through it again. I am thinking of you and hoping you'll be able to get it done soon. Referring to your original post, remember 80% chance of recurrence means 20% chance of not - you just need to be in the 20%. Thinking of you xx Cassie xx
Posts.Title: Deja vu ????

Posts.Content: Hi, Your wife sounds really positive which is great. I couldn't tell anyone or see anyone or go to work. I think you need to be led by her really and just be there for her. Some days carrying on as normal may be best and others she may need some support. Everyone's cancer is individual to them and the way they react to treatments varies so much there isn't a definitive answer. I think nearly all of us felt really fit and healthy prior to diagnosis - it is generally the appearance of a lump that signifies there may be a problem, not any physical pain or feeling unwell. Anyway, well done for joining the site . There are loads of people here to give advice, help and support. Cassie xx
Posts.Title: Hi

Posts.Content: Hi, Up in loft on PC sounds like the best idea to me!!!!! Hope the rads are going OK xx
Posts.Title: TRAVEL INSURANCE

Posts.Content: Hi, No periods for me since first FEC - Onc said at my age (45) the aim was for chemo to practically kill my ovaries hence they won't need to be removed xx Cassie
Posts.Title: Periods on fec-t

Posts.Content: Hi Jo, Hope you're feeling a bit better now - I was admitted after 1st Tax - low white blood cell count but no temperature and was pumped full of precautionary anti biotics. After that I was given a reduced dose (20% less) for the final 2 doses of tax and was fine so they may look at that for you, so if you can just get past this one you'll be on the home straight. Cassie xx
Posts.Title: Had a melt down! Thanks for listening to my sound off!

Posts.Content: Hi, Cold cap must be working for you then!! I am 18 days past first FEC and hair is thinning radically - didn't use cold cap so inevitable I suppose!! Think I might get the clippers out tonight as hubby has just mentioned I have a slightly bald patch on top!! Well done to those of you who persevere with the cold cap - I just couldn't face the extra time having chemo but you get the rewards in the long run. Cassie xxxxxx
Posts.Title: Hair falling out!

Posts.Content: Well done SaxxyD - so glad to hear you can start to enjoy life again. I started rads today so 14 more to go - fed up with it already although all the nurses/radiographers are lovely. Hope you still keep posting on here - it's great to hear from you. Cassie xxxx
Posts.Title: Finished Rads now Tamoxifen!!!

Posts.Content: Hi, Docetaxel chemo made my face go red in places - it lasted several days and I hated it as it was bad enough not having any hair, eyelashes, eyebrows etc, without having that aswell!  xx
Posts.Title: redness in face and new lump

Posts.Content: Hi Sammy99, I know how you feel cos things like that worry me too and I just finished rads yesterday, after chemo which finished in Oct. Please remember that everyones cancer is different and is also diagnosed at different stages so just because we see or hear one sad and terrible story it doesn't mean that your story, my story or anyone elses story will be the same. I must admit I was feeling great yesterday and on a high after finishing my treatment and seeing that (I have 14 and 15 year old girls who need me) made me feel a bitndesperate for a while.....BUT I have had the best treatment I could have for this and so have you. I will be on Tamoxifen for the next 5 years and I am determined in my own mind to stay strong and not allow it to come back. My Onc on Wednesday said 'don't allow what has happened to rule the rest of your life - go sky dive, bounce on the trampoline, do whatever you want and live your life'. Maybe easier said than done but if I sit at home worrying it will have won. You are doing really well - you are nearly at the end of chemo and rads is a breeze after that. It is infuriating when people say you look well when you feel like crap, but I decided it is better than them saying you look awful so I just smiled (like you) and kept going - maybe it's a coping mechanism. When you do get to the end of rads and feel soooo much better like I do, hopefully you will make more sense of it all and realise you are going to be OK. Hugs. Cassie xx
Posts.Title: Tears - feeling low

Posts.Content: You are doing great - just keep up the good work. Thinking of you xxxxx
Posts.Title: its spread so scared

Posts.Content: Hi Mandi, FEC is horrible - I found it worse than docetaxel because it made me feel so shaky and wispy - I couldn't settle to anything and drifted from room to room not staying anywhere for more than about 10 minutes. I did sleep quite a lot too....BUT, the second dose was much better with much less side effects and the third dose went so well I dreaded swapping to Docetaxel, so there is hope that things will get better for you xx I had a Picc line and it drove me mad for the first two weeks. The line dug into my arm and made it sore and I had pins and needles and it constantly needed re-dressing because it bled a lot. However, the Onc said it would settle down after 2 weeks and it did exactly that, after which I had no trouble at all with it and by the time it was removed I never gave it a thought. It was defo worth it for the chemo as not worrying about needles made it much easier. Try not to worry about it all - I'm sure both the chemo and the Picc line will get better xx Cassie xx
Posts.Title: 1st fec

Posts.Content: Hi Well done for getting away xx Try not to worry too much - chemo works whether the lump is there or gone so it can only have got smaller and can't have spread. I would still ask them about surgery though as I understood from my Onc when I was initially diagnsed and worried, that they could still operate under such circumstances. Maybe try and say what you want rather than accept what they want to give you - I have found it does work sometimes. Good luck and thinking of you. Cassie xxxxxx
Posts.Title: Terrified of ONC appt tomorrow :(

Posts.Content: Hi, I had my last chemo - T - on 4th October so well done all you who are through or nearly through!! There is definitely a deep sense of relief that I haven't got to sit in that chemo suite and have thse drugs pumped into me again. Strangely, I think I coped with T much better than FEC so there is hope that it may not be too bad. Good luck and sending loads of hugs to you all. Cassie xxx
Posts.Title: Just had my last Chemo!!

Posts.Content: Hi Well done for getting away xx Try not to worry too much - chemo works whether the lump is there or gone so it can only have got smaller and can't have spread. I would still ask them about surgery though as I understood from my Onc when I was initially diagnsed and worried, that they could still operate under such circumstances. Maybe try and say what you want rather than accept what they want to give you - I have found it does work sometimes. Good luck and thinking of you. Cassie xxxxxx
Posts.Title: Terrified of ONC appt tomorrow :(

Posts.Content: Hi, My hair started falling out about 2 weeks after first chemo and I shaved it off as it was driving me mad. Also, because I was quite sick on FEC I wanted to sort my hair out before I felt yucky with the second dose. Also, it was easier to wear my wig once my hair wasn't there although I do wear lots of hats too and for a while some of my hair still showed underneath them. Even now, I have some hair on my head although I look more like a new born baby than a grown up!!! Good luck whatever you decide xxxx
Posts.Title: hair :-(

Posts.Content: Hi both, First of all good luck Kittycat with your surgery on Thursday - promise we must meet up after that and my last docetaxel on Thursday. Hopefully we will both be back to normal soon!! I know what you mean about feeling tired. I have just gone through a bout of it and also my muscles from my knees to my thighs ache, but it's all bearable at the moment so I hope you will feel better soon. I have a feeling it does stay in the body and affect you for some time - my husband is under the impression that I will be back to fitness in 3 weeks time!!!! probably not quite!!!!! I think perhaps you should check with someone if you're feeling really tired as it would help if you knew it was normal or expected before you have your op. Sue, I would feel deserted if my Onc says he doesn't want to see me for a year. I know we are brave ladies but I feel some form of support and reassurance would be nice. I expected it would be every 3 months to start with and then 6 months etc. I have a pre chemo review tomorrow so I will ask my Onc what happens at Northampton and let you know - if he says a year I will not be a happy bunny!! Hugs to you both. Cassie xxx
Posts.Title: Docetaxal - how long until you feel better??!!

Posts.Content: Hi, Can't answer about hot flushes and radiotherapy because I'm still on chemo, but the area where I had the mx and lymph node clearance at the end of April still feels numb and tingly (although I think it's improving slowly). When did your hot flushes start? Cassie xxx
Posts.Title: Hot Sweats and radiotherapy !

Posts.Content: Hi I do feel for you but you are doing so well. You have your treatment in place and doing what you feel is right for you under the most difficult circumstances - I am sure you will be jigging us all along again soon, Love and hugs, Cassie xxx
Posts.Title: Feeling blue

Posts.Content: Hi Amy, I felt young and I'm 45 - I am so sorry you're having to go through this too - I had a fear of even going to the Oncology area cos it looked soooo clinical. Having said that, everyone was really nice and I did soon get used to it. Hope you are able to take someone with you for support and company. Will be thinking of you. Hugs. Cassie xxxx
Posts.Title: chemo day 2moro

Posts.Content: Hi, You should defo be on here. The important reason for joining is because we all have breast cancer or know someone who has, not the treatment we have chosen to fix it. I admire you for deciding what's right for you and telling us all about it. I would do the same if I had a medical history that did not suit chemo. I was tempted to go down the alternative route but decided in the end I would have the chemo and then look at alternatives to help prevent any recurrence. So, basically, good luck to you and keep posting - we need to hear what else is out there and how it is working. Cassie xxx
Posts.Title: Not sure if I still belong here or not?

Posts.Content: Hiya, I know how you feel - I am heading towards my last chemo and then radiotherapy and am wondering how I will feel after that. All the time I am being treated I feel as if something is helping to fight against it. Will you be on Tamoxifen - I suppose I feel that will be the way to keep it at bay when radiotherapy is finished. I am also determined to keep off all the weight I have lost and do everything I can such as excercise and diet etc. to keep it away. However, I was pretty fit and healthy prior to being diagnosed so I don't know what else I can do really. I have decided to try and live my life, go for checkups and not worry until I am told there is a problem and I need to worry - not easy to do but if I live my life worrying every day I will be breathing but not living and that's not me. Sorry I can't be more helpful. I really feel for you and hope you find a way to get through this - I am sure I will struggle to when my last appointment is done. Hugs, Cassie xxxxx
Posts.Title: What now ?

Posts.Content: Hi Kiera, Hope your op goes OK. I would defo try and keep going to the gym if you can during chemo. I rode my horse regularly through chemo and it was great just because you can still do something you like doing at a time when lots of things aren't much fun. I am sure it helped to combat tiredness, kept me fit and helped my recovery. I even rode 2 weeks after my mx - I just didn't tell my consultant!!! Cassie xx
Posts.Title: Can't wait to have my mx operation

Posts.Content: Hi All, Really useful to hear all the hints and tips - glad it's going well for you all. I have one more lot of FEC then move on to Docetaxal so it's reassuring to hear that it hasn't been too bad xx
Posts.Title: Docetaxal question

Posts.Content: In Northampton you are entitled to a free NHS wig. There is a lady based in the Oncology department who helps with all aspects of hair and beauty. I tried several on and she is going to order the three I liked in the colours I liked for me to choose. One of their suppliers is a good wig maker in Banbury. I was very impressed. I also tried on some scarves but they are so not me.....I have found choosing your headwear is, at least, a good distraction!! C xx
Posts.Title: Wig business

Posts.Content: Hi Kate - I'm sure you will pass your final test with honours - I really hope you do but I also hope you don't give up posting at that point - we need you!! I finished treatment mid November and am on Tamoxifen for 5 years (started 2nd Dec 2012). I don't consider myself a survivor, I'm just relieved to still be here and say I had cancer but I don't have it now. Cassie xxx
Posts.Title: When does survival start officially?

Posts.Content: Hi, I was the same - just wanted to get the cancer out and get it over with. It took a while before I could look at the wound but you soon get used to it and it all mends so quickly with very little pain. 6 weeks on I feel great and ready to take on the world (apart from the cording) but unfortunately I have 6 chemo sessions to get through starting on 21st June so starting to dread next week. Just try and take one day at a time and don't think too far ahead otherwise you start to worry about things which may never happen. C xx
Posts.Title: rambling thoughts

Posts.Content: Hi Annie, I agree with SaxxyD - try and concentrate on the good things and don't look further than a day ahead. Lets face it, if the world had ended yesterday, as some said it was going to, none of this would matter anymore. Concentrate on the 'now' and try to forget the past and the future for a bit....Tax is hideous and makes you feel awful which doesn't help with trying to think straight. Try not to google because I have tried and you can go from feeling really positive to incredibly negative in a few seconds (and back again sometimes), depending on what you read. Remember, everyones cancer is different and other factors such as age, general health and fitness and lifestyle are considerations which probably aren't included in prognosis and stats. You are you so try and stick with that and tell the nasty cells to s** off. Love and hugs on a horrible and wet saturday which I am sure doesn't help. C xxxx
Posts.Title: Mirztipine

Posts.Content: Hi SaxxyD, Sorry you're still having problems after Tax (and SuperSue too). I've just had 3rd FEC so onto Tax next and still dreading it. Onc said he didn't want to see me for another 6 weeks but I said I wanted to see him before Tax to discuss pain relief etc. He said many don't have SE's but that's not what it sounds like on here and they have given me 24 steroids to take 8, the day before, 8 on the day of chem and 8 the day after - is that normal?? I really admire anyone who manages to go through this alone, or who have children to look after without help. I don't know how you cope. I have support of a husband and my parents who muck in to help and sort out my teenage girls who are pretty good anyway. For the first week after FEC I really struggle to do much and feel really washed out (and sick for the first evening....I am sure I couldn't cope on my own so hats off to all of you that do. Cassie xx
Posts.Title: Living alone

Posts.Content: Hi Sue, Glad you're sorted. I am having a similar problem with a new laptop with windows 8 on it, so I'll try installing google chrome!!! Best wishes for the new year xx
Posts.Title: Logging on problems. Is it just me ???

Posts.Content: Hi SaxxyD, Thanks for the support and sound advice as usual xx Hope you are feeling better xxx Love and hugs, Cassie xxxx
Posts.Title: Living alone

Posts.Content: Hi, I very rarely post on here but I saw yours and felt I had to say something. I totally understand how you feel - I have been there too. I had pretty much everything thrown at my BC in 2012 at the age of 44 and at the end of it felt like you. I still do. I never feel safe - it is like living with an enemy which may attack you as soon as you let your guard down. Every Christmas, every Birthday is a time to think 'is it my last'? But, I remember being told that it will get better and it honestly does. I have learnt to live with it, to forget it for a while, to hope that I will be OK. I have also learnt to live life to the full - ride horses, travel, climb mountains, be amazing. No one knows what the future holds and I am sure it is harder for you because you have seen so much more of this horrible disease but you, like me, have a lot to live for. So go and live. You've got this far, you're doing great, you can do it.. Love and hugs from me xxxxxx
Posts.Title: Feeling Morbid

Posts.Content: Hi, Think chemo can cause conjunctivitis. I had sore eyes too and got eye drops from the Onc. Worked a treat. Cassie xxx
Posts.Title: Sore eyes

Posts.Content: Hi, I agree with Sue. My horrible mouth was really why I ended up being checked out in hospital and staying in for a few days, due to low white blood cell count even though I didn't have a temperature. Nystan works well for me too. Cassie xx
Posts.Title: Docetaxol You B*****D !!!

Posts.Content: Brilliant news SaxxyD - sooooooooo relieved. I have a big smile on my face for you. Love and hugs, Cassie xxxxx
Posts.Title: Worrying scan results

Posts.Content: Hi SaxxyD, Bloody C is going to get a good kicking from me too if it's anywhere near you still after all you've been through. Thinking of you loads. Love and hugs lovely lady. Cassie xxxxx
Posts.Title: Worrying scan results

Posts.Content: Thinking of you all and hoping it all works out for you. Somehow the waiting is the worst. I think back to being diagnosed and how those small works 'It is cancer' change your life so much. If they could have just said it is a cyst it would have all been sooooo different. However, whatever gets thrown at us we will deal with it and get through it. Finished chemo today and don't like the thought of having to go through anything more than rads now and tamoxifen. I asked my Onc about follow ups and he said 6 months with a surgeon and then another 6 months before I see him ie: a year from when he sees me after rads. That sounds similar to wht you said the other day Sue. I find it bizarre that they aren't going to check chemo has worked etc. It seems such pot luck. Maybe chemo was never needed, maybe chemo was needed and worked, maybe it will work for a while, maybe it hasn't worked at all.....who knows. The only way for me to deal with this is to live each day to the full while I can and be grateful that I am alive. SaxxyD - I am sure your scans will be fine - we worry about every ache and pain I know but you are a brave, strong lovely lady and you have been through loads and always come out the other side OK xxx Shelley - I think Caroline is right - one thing I did while waiting for my initial results was to use a technique where you parcel you worry into a little box under the bed and leave it there each night. It seemed to work for me as it was just like taking the thoughts out of my brain and putting them in a box and all the worry went away so I could sleep. It may not help but it's worth a try. Sending you big hugs and thinking of you loads xxx Kittycat - hope the surgery went well. Please let me know when you are up to a visitor as I guess you my not be mobile immediately xxx Love to all, Cassie xxxx
Posts.Title: Worrying scan results

Posts.Content: Hi Kelly, I had a mastectomy and node clearance at the end of April and found that the first part is almost the hardest as it's the constant trips to the hospital, the huge aount of information you have to take in and the constant worry. Things do settle down once your treatment plan is confirmed, but you just have to take one day at a time and not worry about things which may never happen in the future. If you can talk your anxieties through with someone that often helps. I used a qualified life coach who coaches sports people but also people with illness. This put things into perspective and made me realise that a lot I was worrying about was unfounded and just me being anxious. The hospital also offered an appointment with a clinical phsycologist but there was a waiting list. I also looked on the internet a lot for alternative therapies, diets etc. anything which may help (not at success rates, prognosis or anything scary like that). If nothing else, it made me feel proactive and more in control Being told you have cancer when you didn't suspect it and feel 100% well is a massive shock to the system and takes a long time to come to terms with. I was angry for ages and couldn't cry at all so there is no normal way to react - we are all individuals and our cancer is too. Keep posting on here - everyone is great and there is always someone here to answer you. Love C xx
Posts.Title: I'm new and just been diagnosed.

Posts.Content: Brilliant news. Well done. As someone who finished treatment at the end of November and has been back at work since January after 9 months of treatment, I know how you must be feeling. Rads are a breeze after chemo and then it's onwards and upwards again. Love and hugs, C xxxx
Posts.Title: Today I am a cancer survivor :)

Posts.Content: Hi, I was diagnosed April 2012 so it's nearly a year since I started my 6 sessions of chemo - how fast it has all gone. It is lovely to pop back here and recognise so many names (I changed my name from Catharine Mill to Sparky121 so you may not recognise me!!). I have been back at work since Christmas so haven't found so much time to post but log in every few weeks!! It's great to hear how you're all getting along and lovely that for a lot of us, last years nightmare roller coaster ride is becoming a thing of the past. I just wish I could stop my brain reminding me all the time - I wish I could be as I was before. I am back to normal in that I work, do everything I used to do  (and more probably!!) and really live my life, but it is always with me - does it ever go away...... Anyway, love and hugs to you all - you really are amazing xxxx Cassie xxxx
Posts.Title: 14 months later :-))

Posts.Content: Thanks Dorothee - that's a great way of putting it. I do actually better for reading that. xxx
Posts.Title: 14 months later :-))

Posts.Content: Hi Scarlett93, Try and concentrate on the fact that it showed as a cyst - it seems from what you say that they had been happy to leave it for another 6 months. At least by having an ultrasound, presumably they can tell for sure what it is. Try not to worry about things in the future as they may never happen. Sorry I can't be of more help, but one thing I have realised with this cancer rubbish is that it is almost 95% mental and 5% physical in a strange sort of way. If you can get your head clear and not let the worrying thoughts creep in, it seems to help somehow. Not easy I know but good luck - I am thinking of you and wishing you the very best. Big hugs. Cassie xxx
Posts.Title: soo scared and not sleeping i am having a liver ultra sound
